content: The files must have been restored to a different location, depending on your backup and restore. If restored properly, the profile would be at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird. Also, if the backup was done while Thunderbird was running, the backup would be missing key files.

content:
If Thunderbird isn't appearing on your new computer, here are some steps you can take to resolve the issue:

Check Installation: Make sure Thunderbird is installed on your new computer. You can download it from the official Thunderbird website.

Search Your Computer: Use the search function in Windows (click the magnifying glass icon or press Windows + S) and type "Thunderbird" to see if it appears.

Check the Start Menu: Go to the Start Menu and scroll through the list of installed programs to see if Thunderbird is there.

Create a Shortcut: If Thunderbird is installed but you can't find it easily, you can create a desktop shortcut. Go to the installation folder (usually C:\Program Files\Mozilla Thunderbird), find thunderbird.exe, right-click it, and select "Create shortcut." Drag the shortcut to your desktop.

Reinstall Thunderbird: If you can't find Thunderbird or it's not working properly, try uninstalling and reinstalling it.

Transfer Profile: If you had Thunderbird set up on your old computer and want to transfer your emails and settings, you'll need to copy the Thunderbird profile from the old computer to the new one. The profile folder is usually located at C:\Users\[Your Username]\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\.

If you still encounter issues, let me know the specific problem, and I can provide more targeted advice!
creator: adamjackir

content:
It may help if you post a screenshot of your profile, as it should have appeared with earlier instructions. Assuming what you have just the complete profile, here are detail steps for a fresh install: 

Thunderbird must be already installed but not running

- copy the profile to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles - start thunderbird. if pane to create email account appears, close it - click alt key to show menu bar if not visible - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down left side to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles' -click 'create profile' - click next - enter short nickname for folder, such as MYPROFILE - click choose' button - locate and select your profile and click finish - on next pane, locate your profile and click the 'launch' button

content:
'ADDITIONAL INFORMATION: I think I claimed that I sent this from Gmail with the unrecognized Greek letters. It came from a different mailing list server, not Gmail. I sent myself this email from Gmail, with a PDF attachment as before, and in both cases, the Subject line and body, together with the document, were all in Base64 encoding.

The mail that I sent from Gmail was received with the Greek letters DISPLAYED in Thunderbird.

It is a limitation of the mailing list server that causes the question marks to appear in the text, and that is all in several hundreds of kilobytes of Base64 encoding. In the More… menu, I saw where I can "repair" the encoding guesswork. That changed nothing. The plain English and the middle dots I typed into my document all look as I sent them.

This issue is not with Thunderbird. The accelerator, brake and gearshift work just fine—ahh, not THAT Thunderbird!  :)

I will mark this issue solved.

content:
re :Some are in my all mail, but not all Are you talking about a gmail mail account ? Gmail stores all your emails incoming and outgoing etc - everything in the 'All Mail' folder. There is no need to see that folder because it's just a duplicate of everything you alreay see except for anything you archive. Be careful with that 'All Mail' folder - you delete anything and it will gone from everywhere. If it's not up to date, selecting the 'All Mail' folder usually forces it to synchronise and update. But it's going to be one massive file to update.

If emails are not in 'All Mail' folder - as checked via webmail account using a browser then they do not exist.

If you want to see that 'All Mail' folder then please make sure you do not have any type of Anti-Virus product scanning anything in your profile folders. If it tries to fix that 'All mail' folder you stand a good chance of losing everything. Personally, I would advise you do not subscribe to see it.

1. Please check you have not inadvertantly switched on a filter.

Select problem Inbox Then check the 'Quick Filter' toolbar. If you see any icon that is displaying a blue strip then click on that icon to remove the filter.

2. Check to see if you managed to set up a ignore thread' In Menu Bar

  • View > Threads > Select 'All' should be set up, but also select 'Ignored threads' to see if the emails reappear.

They would typically have a red circle type icon in thread column. Info on ignored threads

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/ignore-threads
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
The reason I say check you have not set up 'ignored threads' is because it can be easily done. If you have an email selected and you press the 'K' key then you are setting an 'ignore thread' on the selected email.

If have known some one who selected/highlighted a batch of emails and then decided to invoke the Global Search by using Ctrl+K, but they accidentally pressed the K before the Ctrl key and instantly set up a load of emails as ignored.


Do you have any Message Filters which you created ? If yes, then you could check the 'Filter Log' to see what it's done with certain emails. If you have not enabled the Filter Log then perhaps it would be a good idea to do it so it's availble to check in the future.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Trying to understand the issue. re :my wife and I, have 5 different email addresses, all of which WERE on the same inbox

You had 5 pop accounts and all of them had been set up as deferred accounts - In Folder Pane you did not see all the individual pop accounts with individual folders - You just have the 'Local Folders' account and it stored all incoming mail from all pop accounts.

At this point you had this set up for each pop account in Account Settings - you may still have this set up on Laptop.

  • Selected 'Server Settings' for pop account
  • Clicked on 'Advanced' button
  • Selected 'Inbox for different account' and chose 'Global Inbox (Local Folders)'
  • Selected Include this server when getting new mail
  • clicked on OK

re : After this spring move to DT, all 5 had different accounts and inboxes. So, somehow the Server SEttings had been altered. Now you have :

  • Selected 'Server Settings' for pop account
  • Clicked on 'Advanced' button
  • Selected 'Inbox for this servers account'
  • clicked on OK

In the Folder Pane, you now see each pop account as a separate set of folders and all new incoming mail is using those folders. But all the old mail is still in 'Local Folders', however it is very incomplete. Meaning you now had a good set of emails on Laptop but not on Desktop.

Then you found another profile - There was an unused Profile that had all of the Local Folder folders in it.

This sounds like you have created a new profile for the pop accounts and set them up as separate accounts.

OK-

So at this point please confirm the following to ensure I've got this correct. The Desktop is set up for each account to use it's own folders. Some Local Folders emails but it is incomplete. It also has an old original profile which you believe to have a load of old emails in Local Folders.

It sounds like the laptop is still correct - In Folder Pane there is only 'Local Folders'. It still has all the pop accounts using 'Local Folders' and you can see all the emails.

Q: Does the laptop have everything correct? if yes then you need to get a proper copy of whatever is on the laptop and put it on the desktop,


First make sure you are using the same identical version of Thunderbird on both Laptop and Desktop. This is important because different versions may have a different file format etc and profiles use a dedicated profile for version.

Then make sure the Firewall on both Laptop and Desktop has Thunderbird set up as an allowed program. The Firewall may the computer default or controlled by an Anti-Virus program which you installed. This ensures the Firewall will not block anything.

If you want everything you see on LAPTOP to be on DESKTOP do the following. I've added an image below as a guide to help you locate correct location.

I'm assuming you use 'User Accounts' on Desktop and Laptop and that everything is stored in the default locations.

On LAPTOP Exit Thunderbird if it's running

Use Windows search:

  • type %Appdata%
  • select %Appdata% file folder
  • Select 'Roaming'
  • Copy the 'Thunderbird' folder to an external drive.

On Desktop: Exit Thunderbird if it's running

Use Windows search:

  • type %Appdata%
  • select %Appdata% file folder
  • Select 'Roaming'
  • 'Move' the 'Thunderbird' folder because you are going to replace it.

I suggest 'Move' to your desktop as a temporary location because you said it contains old emails in Local Folders. Those emails may be on the laptop anyway so could end up being copied over. You can always delete it later on if all emails area ok.

  • Paste the copied from laptop 'Thunderbird' folder from external drive into the 'Roaming' folder.

Start Thunderbird on Desktop and it will look identical to Thuderbird on Laptop.

I'm not sure how you have been copying between Desktop and Laptop in the past but the instructions I've given are the correct and only way to ensure both are identical.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re Error message (can't send full screen shot):

How to create an image of what you see on monitor. Use the 'prt scr' key on keyboard. Open a simple image program like Paint Use Ctrl+V to put screendump into Paint - edit as required and save as a jpeg image file in a suitable eay to locate place eg: desktop Then in this forum use the Add images 'Browse' button to locate the saved jpg image file and clickon Open to upload.


The error message says : Login to server smtp.comcast.net with username carp,jm@comcast.net failed. The bit that says the server name - it says smtp meaning you are trying to send an email when it fails.

So you have to check the smtp setting you have for comcast account.

  • In 'Account Settings'
  • Scroll to bottom of left pane and look below Local Folders.
  • You will see 'Outgoing Server (SMTP)' - click on it.
  • On the right it will show you a list of all your outgoing servers.
  • Each mail account/email address will have it's own smtp server specifically for that email address.
  • starting at the top of the list, select each one in turn until you find the one that has the incorrect 'User Name' -
  • click on 'Edit'

Edit the following:

  • Description: Enter the full correct email address which should be the same as the 'User name' - this means you use that description to check the account is using the correct smtp.
  • User Name: edit the email address so it is corrected.
  • click on OK

Now check that mail account is using that smtp.

  • In Account Settings
  • In left pane - select the account name for the carp.jim comcast mail account
  • Look bottom right for it's Outgoing Server SMTP - it should display what you entered in the 'Description' field.
  • If yes it's using the correct one, then that's ok.
  • If no, it's pointing to something else then clickon the drop down and select the correct one where Description matches name/email address of account.

NOTE- DO NOT click on the 'Edit SMTP_Server' button or you may edit the wrong smtp - leave it alone :)

Finally exit Thunderbird. Wait a few moments for background preocess to complete and then restart Thunderbird. This ensures all updated information has been copied into preference files.
creator: Toad-Hall
